template:docs/default-options.title: Deafult options
template:docs/default-options.text: Deafult options App wide options can be set in the emberSkeletonOptions object, which must be a child of in the ENV object in config/environment.js. The defaults are as follows: Any additional settings can be added to the emberSkeletonOptions object. These are made available in the options property of the emberSkeleton service. Theme color string defaults Allows you to define default settings for use by the ember-skeleton/theme-color-string helper. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. The above settings would allow the following three use cases. passed absent failed Theme icon defaults Allows you to define default settings for use by the ember-skeleton/theme-icon-string helper. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString.

template:docs/helpers/array-join.title: Array join
template:docs/helpers/array-join.text: Array join Pass an array as the forst argument and the join string as the second. You can optionally pass the named arg finalJoinString to use a different join string for the final item. Simple use List of Parks and Rec characters Custom finalJoinString My favourte characters are .

template:docs/helpers/custom-inflector.title: Custom Inflector
template:docs/helpers/custom-inflector.text: Custom Inflector Determines whether the singular or plural version of a word should be used. Accepts a number as the first argument, ad a hash of the singular and plural versions of the work or phrase. The plural version is optional- if not passed, the plural version of the phrase defaults to the singular version with 's' appended. has . has been voted for .

template:docs/helpers/humanise-string.title: Humanise string
template:docs/helpers/humanise-string.text: Humanise string Accepts a string as the first argument. Replaces underscores with spaces in the string, and applies one of three casing functions: sentenceCase (default) titleCase lowerCase upperCase Name Default Titlecase Lowercase Uppercase

template:docs/helpers/in-array.title: In array
template:docs/helpers/in-array.text: In array The first argument is an array, and then second is the string to find in it. Returns true if it is present, and false if it is not. Name Senior Junior Intern

template:docs/helpers/odd-or-even.title: Odd or even
template:docs/helpers/odd-or-even.text: Odd or even Accepts an integer as the first argument, and returns either odd or even. has an number of votes.

template:docs/helpers/readable-file-size.title: Readable file size
template:docs/helpers/readable-file-size.text: Readable file size Returns a human readable filesize, after receiving a number of bytes as the only argument. Rendering bug Note that versions of Ember lower than 3.18.0 you get unexpected results with long integers, when the integer is passed directly into the helper. The bug does not occur when the argument is in a property as above. (Should be 2.00GB)

template:docs/helpers/replace-string.title: Replace string
template:docs/helpers/replace-string.text: Replace string Receives a string to search for as the first argument, and then either a search tem and a replace term (simple search), or an array of search and replace hashes (advanced search). Note that the value of the default hash will be returned if the string is not found in any of the hashes. Note that the helper only looks for an exact matches- it does not replace text within string that is being searched. Simple Usage The example below replaces "Andy Dwyer" with "Andrew Dwyer". Name Status Advanced Usage Th example below replaces numerical statuses with string statuses. Name Status Array Note that you can pass an array as the find property in your advanced search hashes. The examples below replaces both "0" and "-1" with "false", and "1" with "true". Name Passed Using a find array with the advanced hash: Name Passed Fallback You can pass a fallback string to the helper. If no matches are found, the fallback dtring will be returned. The example below replaces "1" with "passed" and everything else with "did not pass". Name Passed Using fallback with the advanced hash: Name Passed If there are no matches and no fallback is passed, the original string is returned.

template:docs/helpers/robotise-string.title: Robotise string
template:docs/helpers/robotise-string.text: Robotise string Accepts a string as the first argument, and a separator as an optional second argument, which defaults to _ if absent. ` Name Default Custom separator

template:docs/helpers/theme-color-string.title: Theme Color String
template:docs/helpers/theme-color-string.text: Theme Color String Use case The styles documentation outlines how you can define a map of theme colours, which then generates classes for displaying a range of UI elements in any of the defined colours. See Theme colours and Theme colour CSS selectors in Styles". Often we want to associate strings in our data with certain colours- for example, a green badge for a data item with a status of complete and a red badge for an item with a status of failed, as below. complete absent failed With the badges above, the green and red backgrounds come form the badge-success and badge-danger classes respectively. But when using dynamic data, for example in the loop below, hard coding the class of the badge doesn't work- notice how each status below appears in a green badge. Name Status Likewise, simply passing in the status as he relevant part of the badge doesn't work, because there are no theme colours named passed, failed or absent. Name Status Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-color-string helper accepts a string as the first argument (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value is one of the defined theme colours. The helper returns the relevant theme colour, and thus, the badges below display correctly. Name Status Default options It is likely that most colour/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the success colour and failed will always use the danger colour. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js, for example as below. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the helper as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return the lowercased input string. info

template:docs/helpers/theme-icon.title: Theme Icon
template:docs/helpers/theme-icon.text: Theme Icon Use case Often we want to associate strings in our data with certain icons- for example, a tick for a data item with a status of complete and an alert for an item with a status of failed, as below. complete failed But when using dynamic data, for example in the loop below, hard coding the path to the icon component doesn't work- notice how each icon below is a tick. Name Status Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-icon helper accepts a string as the first arguemnt (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value the path to a component. The helper returns the relevant path, and thus the correct icon component is displayed. Name Status Note the use of the contextual component syntax {{component this....}} is used above to render a component from a dynamic path. Default options It is likely that most icon/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the a tick and failed will always use the alert. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponding returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the helper as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return null. info

template:docs/index.title: What is Ember Skeleton
template:docs/index.text: What is Ember Skeleton A frame for building Ember apps that: provides basic layouts for common app designs includes a custom styling API incoporates styles from existing frameworks like Bootstrap and Material Deisgn provides helpers and utils to make templating easier in a real world sense

template:docs/layout-components/content-.title: Content wrapper
template:docs/layout-components/content-.text: Content wrapper To be used inside either of the they panel or sidebar layouts. Creates what you could think of as the main content area of the page, and implements text styles for "main content" text. Accepts one argument- the main title to be displayed on the page. template:docs/layout-components/footer-c.title: Footer component
template:docs/layout-components/footer-c.text: Footer component To create your own footer component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/footer, or specify a custom path in the footerComponent property in your "app wide default options" . footerProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/footer-layout components, you can supply a hash as the footerProps property, and that hash will be available in your footer component.

template:docs/layout-components/header-c.title: Header component
template:docs/layout-components/header-c.text: Header component To create your own header component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/header, or specify a custom path in the headerComponent property in your app wide default options. headerProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/sidebar-layout components, you can supply a hash as the headerProps property, and that hash will be available in your header component.

template:docs/layout-components/loading-.title: Loading component
template:docs/layout-components/loading-.text: Loading component This is what will display in the main content area of your layout when in loading state. See page loading state" on how to show and hide the loading component. To create your own loading component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/loading-page, or specify a custom path in the loadingComponent property in your app wide default options". loadingProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/loading-layout components, you can supply a hash as the loadingProps property, and that hash will be available in your loading component.

template:docs/layout-components/sidebar-.title: Sidebar component
template:docs/layout-components/sidebar-.text: Sidebar component To create your own sidebar component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/sidebar, or specify a custom path in the sidebarContentComponent property in your app wide default options". sidebarProps When inserting the ember-skeleton/sidebar-layout component, you can supply a hash as the sidebarProps property, and that hash will be available in your sidebar component. collapseSideBarIconComponent By default, the sidebar is collapsible, and features an expand/collapse icon, which rotates 180 degress when the sidebar is collapsed or expanded. To create your own icon, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/svg/icon-collapse-sidebar, or specify a custom path in the collapseSideBarIconComponent property in your app wide default options".

template:docs/main-page-layouts/panel-la.title: Panel layout
template:docs/main-page-layouts/panel-la.text: Panel layout Created a layout with a horizontal panel spanning the full width of the screen. The content is centred within it. Invoked as below. Content here.

template:docs/main-page-layouts/sidebar-.title: Sidebar layout
template:docs/main-page-layouts/sidebar-.text: Sidebar layout Includes a sidebar to the left, and a main content section to the right. The content is aligned to the left of the main content section. Invoked as below. If content header is true, the class content-header is added to the wrapper div, and the styles add additional padding to the top of the right hand section (The main section) allowing an additional fixed bar to be placed at the top of the section. Content here.

template:docs/page-loading-state.title: Page loading state
template:docs/page-loading-state.text: Page loading state By toggling the hideContent property in the emberSkeleton service, you can toggle the main content area of your layouts between loading and loaded state. Your loading state will likely show some form of loading animation or gif, to indicate that a network request is in process. See layout components" on how to customise what displays in loading state. The example below shows how the loading state can be toggled at anytime, and from any Ember class that the emberSkeleton service can be injected into. Automatically toggling the loading state To automatically toggle the loading state of your layouts when Ember data is fetching data, define the loading action in your application route. Customising the loading component

template:docs/styles/box-arrows.title: Box arrows
template:docs/styles/box-arrows.text: Box arrows Adds an arrow to a box. The examples below show all the available combinations of arrow direction and position. .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-left .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-right .box-arrow.arrow-direction-left.arrow-position-top .box-arrow.arrow-direction-left.arrow-position-bottom .box-arrow.arrow-direction-down.arrow-position-right .box-arrow.arrow-direction-down.arrow-position-left .box-arrow.arrow-direction-right.arrow-position-bottom .box-arrow.arrow-direction-right.arrow-position-top By default, the arrow fill will be white, but if the element in question has any of the theme colours applied as a backgroud, the arrow fill will take in that colour. .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-left.bg-success .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-right.bg-warning

template:docs/styles/box-shadow-mixin.title: Box shadow mixin
template:docs/styles/box-shadow-mixin.text: Box shadow mixin The box-shadow mixin accepts two arguments- the position and opacity. The default opacity is 0.16. There are 12 positions available: @include .box-shadow(top) @include .box-shadow(bottom) @include .box-shadow(left) @include .box-shadow(right) @include .box-shadow(topInset) @include .box-shadow(bottomInset) @include .box-shadow(leftInset) @include .box-shadow(rightInset) @include .box-shadow(bottomRight) @include .box-shadow(topRight) @include .box-shadow(bottomLeft) @include .box-shadow(topLeft) The mixin can be given a list of positions to add multiple box shadows to one element. @include box-shadow(topInset, rightInset, bottomInset, leftInset); Opacity can also be passed as the second argument. The default is 0.16. @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.1); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.3); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.5); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.7);

template:docs/styles/flexbox.title: Flexbox styles
template:docs/styles/flexbox.text: Flexbox styles There are flexbox related classes defined in ember-skeleton/app/styles/layout/flex-layouts.scss.

template:docs/styles/introduction.title: Introduction
template:docs/styles/introduction.text: Introduction The styles are implemented using SASS, and thus the ember-cli-sass addon is required. Install by running ember install ember-cli-sass. There are two stylesheets which need to be imported in app/styles/app.scss. Overriding SASS variables All variables listed in app/styles/ember-skeleton/variables can be overridden. This must be done before the import of ember-skeleton-variables. Boostrap integration Several components of Boostrap 4.1 SASS code have been borrowed, some of which have been slightly modified. The original Bootstrap docs are listed below. Note that additional CSS classes have been added to some of these components in the Ember Skeleton SASS code. Bootstrap components Alerts Badge Buttons List group Bootstrap utilities Borders and border radius Colours

template:docs/styles/miscellaneous.title: Miscellaneous classes
template:docs/styles/miscellaneous.text: Miscellaneous classes .inline-block Applies display: inline-block to the element. .position-relative Applies position: relative to the element. .hidden Applies display: none to the element. .bg-transparent Applies background-color: transparent to the element. .hover-pointer The cursor will be a pointer on hover of the element. .monospace Applies the font family assigned to the $monospace-font-family variable to the element. The default value is "Lucida Console", Monaco, "Courier New", Courier, monospace. Spinner Any element with the classes .spinner.on will have a spinning animation. .spinner.on Other All elements have box-sizing: border-box. All elements with role="button" will have cursor: pointer in hover state.

template:docs/styles/spacers.title: Spacers
template:docs/styles/spacers.text: Spacers The SASS API allows you to define spacers, which are used to generate various classes. The defaults are: A version of each class listed below is generated for each defined spacer. padding-{{this.spacer}} padding-y-{{this.spacer}} padding-x-{{this.spacer}} padding-top-{{this.spacer}} padding-right-{{this.spacer}} padding-bottom-{{this.spacer}} padding-left-{{this.spacer}} margin-{{this.spacer}} margin-y-{{this.spacer}} margin-x-{{this.spacer}} margin-top-{{this.spacer}} margin-right-{{this.spacer}} margin-bottom-{{this.spacer}} margin-left-{{this.spacer}} height-{{this.spacer}} width-{{this.spacer}} max-height-{{this.spacer}} max-width-{{this.spacer}} Padding examples The padding is represented by the darker grey areas in the examples below. padding-xxl padding-md padding-x-xl padding-y-xl padding-left-xl Margin examples margin-xl margin-xl margin-xl margin-sm margin-sm margin-sm margin-x-lg margin-x-lg margin-x-lg margin-y-lg margin-y-lg margin-y-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg Height, width, max-width and max-height examples Extending spacers Add additional spacers to the $spacers map in your scss code, before you import ember-skeleton-variables, and ten use in your templates as shown below. Additional spacing classes margin-0 Sets margin to 0 padding-0 Sets padding to 0 width-100 Sets width to 100% last-child-margin-bottom-0 Sets bottom margin to 0, if the element is the past child. margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0 margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0 margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0

template:docs/styles/text.title: Text
template:docs/styles/text.text: Text Font size on the body elemnet Note that the font-size of the body element is hard coded to 62.5% so that within the body element, 1em = 10px. This makes it easy to use the superior em units to size fonts, while thinking of font sizes in pixels. Customising text Any of the variables defined in ember-skeleton/app/styles/ember-skeleton/variables/_text.scss can be overriden to customise text design. All overrides must happen before you import ember-skeleton-variables in your scss. Body text The .body-text class defines styles for the text that falls in the primary content areas of your layouts. This would typically exclude the header, footer and sidebar layouts, as you will likely want to style the text in these elements individually. The .body-text class will be applied to any content wrapped in the ember-skeleton/content-wrapper component (See layouts), but the class can be added to any element. See ember-skeleton/app/styles/ember-skeleton/generic/_text.scss to see all elements that are affected when they are descendants of .body-text. Text align The following classes apply the corresponding value to the text-align property. .text-align-left .text-align-center .text-align-right .text-align-justify Text smaller and text larger Default values (These can be overriden before importing ember-skeleton-variables in your scss.) $text-smaller-size: 0.9em !default; $text-larger-size: 1.2em !default; In addition, the .text-smaller and .text-larger classes Text column class This class is added for use with long form text blocks, so that such blocks can be styled for maximum readability. The following variables can be overriden before importing ember-skeleton-variables. Note that $text-column-justify-paragraph-min-width defines the minimum screen width at which paragraphs inside .text-column must have their text-align property overridden to justify. If null the paragraphs will not have their text-align property overridden. Links no-underline class If the class no-underline is added to any a element, it will not be underlined,in both normal or hover state. Faux link class The .faux-link class will apply all link styles to the element.

template:docs/styles/theme-color-variant.title: Theme color variants
template:docs/styles/theme-color-variant.text: Theme color variants Text colours text-primary text-secondary text-success text-info text-warning text-danger text-light text-dark text-gray-extra-light text-gray-light text-gray-medium text-gray-dark text-white Badges Taken from Bootstrap badge badge-primary badge-secondary badge-success badge-info badge-warning badge-danger badge-light badge-dark badge-gray-extra-light badge-gray-light badge-gray-medium badge-gray-dark badge-white Alerts Taken from Booststrap alerts A simple primary alertcheck it out! A simple secondary alertcheck it out! A simple success alertcheck it out! A simple danger alertcheck it out! A simple warning alertcheck it out! A simple info alertcheck it out! A simple light alertcheck it out! A simple dark alertcheck it out! Buttons Taken from Bootstrap buttons. The .btn class applies general button styles, and btn-{{this.theme-color}} or btn-outline-{{this.theme-color}} applies a theme colour. The class flashing will cause the button to flash between outline state to normal state. Primary Secondary Success Danger Warning Info Light Dark Link Primary Secondary Success Danger Warning Info Light Dark Adding the class flashing will cause the button to chnage between normal and outline state. Flashing button List groups Basic usage .list-group-item .list-group-item.list-group-item-action .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.active .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.disabled Flush Removes the side borders. .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item List group with colour variants .list-group-item.list-group-item-action .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-primary .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-secondary .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-success .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-danger .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-warning .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-info .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-light .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-dark List group header The boostrap list group styles are extended by adding the class .list-group-item-header which applies the font weight defined the the variable $list-group-header-font-weight. The default is 600. Borders Taken from Bootstrap borders .border .border.border-primary .border.border-secondary .border.border-success .border.border-danger .border.border-warning .border.border-info .border.border-light .border.border-dark .border.border-white Border radius Taken from Bootstrap border radius .rounded .rounded-top .rounded-right .rounded-bottom .rounded-left .rounded-circle .rounded-0 Overlay colours Provides a set of classes that apply either a fill or background to an element in RGBa format, thus allowing transparency. The defaults provide both black and white at levels 10, 30 and 50. These numbers refer to percentage opacity. The classes are as follows: .overlay-bg-white-10 .overlay-bg-white-30 .overlay-bg-white-50 .overlay-bg-black-10 .overlay-bg-black-30 .overlay-bg-black-50 .overlay-fill-white-10 .overlay-fill-white-30 .overlay-fill-white-50 .overlay-fill-black-10 .overlay-fill-black-30 .overlay-fill-black-50 .overlay-bg-black-10 .overlay-bg-black-30 .overlay-bg-black-50 .overlay-bg-white-10 .overlay-bg-white-30 .overlay-bg-white-50 The $overlay-colors map can be extended in a similar way to $theme-colors. Additionally, you can customise the levels that are included. Note the the colours must be defined in RGB format. .overlay-bg-green-10 .overlay-bg-green-30 .overlay-bg-green-50 .overlay-bg-green-80 .overlay-bg-red-10 .overlay-bg-red-30 .overlay-bg-red-50 .overlay-bg-red-80 .overlay-bg-blue-10 .overlay-bg-blue-30 .overlay-bg-blue-50 .overlay-bg-blue-80 Fill and stroke colours The Bootstap theme colours have are extended to incldue fill and stroke, for application to SVGs. Overriding fill and stroke for elements inside an svg Note the following variables: $svg-foreground-graphic-fill $svg-foreground-graphic-stroke-color By adding the class foreground-graphic to any element inside an svg, the fill and stoke colours will be whatever the corresponding variables are set to (Default is #fff).

template:docs/styles/theme-colors.title: Theme colours
template:docs/styles/theme-colors.text: Theme colours This concept has been borrowed from Bootstrap. Many of the CSS classes available in the styles API are based on a map of theme colours, defined in the $theme-colors variable. The defaults are shown below. Theme color CSS selectors The Ember Skeleton SASS code will create multiple CSS style rules for each of the selectors listed below- one for each item in the $theme-colors map. See Theme color variants" for the full CSS API based on theme colours. .alert-* .badge-* .bg-* .text-* .list-group-item-* .fill-* .stroke-* .btn-* .btn-outline-* Button theme colours If you don't want the full map of $theme-colors applied to buttons, you can define a buttons specific map and pass it to the variable $button-theme-colors. The format is the same a the &theme-colors variable. This map of colours will then be used to generate the colour variants of the .btn-* and .btn-outline-* variants. Adding custom theme colors Custom colours can be added to this map, by defining your own $theme-colors map before importing ember-skeleton-variables. Note that the above code will add the colours to the default $theme-colors` map, rather than replace it. The corresponding classes will then be avilable in your CSS. The below example shows bootstrap badges implemented with custom theme colours defined above. badge-twitter badge-facebook badge-tripadvisor badge-reddit Bootstrap YIQ threshold Some bootstrap components apply bootstrap colours tot he backgrounds of elements that will have text in theme- for example .badge-* and .btn-*. In order for such text to remain readable, it may need to be dark in some cases, and light in others. Note that the Tripadvisor badge has dark text above, while the Reddit badge has white text. Both a light and dark text color are defined by the $yiq-text-dark and $yiq-text-light variables. The $yiq-contrasted-threshold variable is a measure of when a colour is light enough to require dark text on top of it. It can be anything from 0 to 255. The default is 160. The higher this value is, the lighter a background is allowed to be, while still maintaining light text on top of it. Att 255 text will always be white, and at 0, text will always be dark.

template:docs/utility-components/materia.title: Material Card
template:docs/utility-components/materia.text: Material Card Adds static classes to a component to give it rounded corners, large padding, a border and box shadow effect. Basic usage Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Depth The depth prop sets the depth of the box shadow based on the Google Material Design spec. The default is 1, max is 5. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Hover effect If the materialCardHoverEffect prop is true, a hover effect will be applied when the user hovers over the card. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Theme color integration Uses the defined theme colours" along with theme color string helper" to apply a coloured borde to the car, based on the borderColorProp. The simplest scenario is when borderColorProp is the name of one of the theme colours. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. The second scenario is where the borderColorProp is not one of the defined theme colours", but it is handled by the theme color string defaults in config/environment.js. | You can pass a hash of custom theme color string associations using the themeColorStringHash prop. Note that you can also pass fallback="..." to this hash to provide a fallback border color. See the theme color string helper docs" for more. | Usage by class extension You can make any component into a material card component by extending the material-card component class. import MaterialCard from 'ember-skeleton/components/ember-skeleton/material-card'; export default MaterialCard.extend({ ... });

template:docs/utils/array-join.title: Array join
template:docs/utils/array-join.text: Array join Pass an array as the first argument and the join string as the second. You can optionally pass the named arg finalJoinString to use a different join string for the final item. Example

template:docs/utils/custom-inflector.title: Custom Inflector
template:docs/utils/custom-inflector.text: Custom Inflector Determines whether the singular or plural version of a word should be used. Accepts a number as the first argument, ad a hash of the singular and plural versions of the work or phrase. The plural version is optional- if not passed, the plural version of the phrase defaults to the singular version with 's' appended. Import the util Usage

template:docs/utils/custom-sort-objects.title: Custom sort objects
template:docs/utils/custom-sort-objects.text: Custom sort objects Order an array of javascript objects according to a key, but rather than using ascending or descending order, specify an order by passing an array of values to be matched, in the relevant order. Objects in the array which are not matched are appended to the end of the returned array. RegExp can also be passed as an order item.

template:docs/utils/odd-or-even.title: Odd or even
template:docs/utils/odd-or-even.text: Odd or even Accepts an integer as the first argument, and returns either odd or even. Import the util Usage

template:docs/utils/readable-file-size.title: Readable file size
template:docs/utils/readable-file-size.text: Readable file size Returns a human readable filesize, after receiving a number of bytes as the only argument. Import the util Usage

template:docs/utils/robotise-string.title: Robotise string
template:docs/utils/robotise-string.text: Robotise string Accepts a string as the first argument, and a separator as an optional second argument, which defaults to _ if absent. ` Example Name Default Custom separator

template:docs/utils/theme-color-string.title: Theme Color String
template:docs/utils/theme-color-string.text: Theme Color String Use case In general, you should be using the helper" directly in your templates. The util should only be used when this is not possible. For a general explanation of the use case, see the helper docs". Import the util Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-color-string util accepts a string as the first argument (person.status in the example below), and an object as the second argument, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value is one of the defined theme colours. The helper returns the relevant theme colour, and thus, the badges below display correctly. Name Status Default options It is likely that most colour/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the success colour and failed will always use the danger colour. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js, for example as below. The util will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the util as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return the lowercased input string. info

template:docs/utils/theme-icon.title: Theme Icon
template:docs/utils/theme-icon.text: Theme Icon Use case In general, you should be using the helper" directly in your templates. The util should only be used when this is not possible. For a general explanation of the use case, see the helper docs". Import the util Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-icon helper accepts a string as the first arguemnt (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value the path to a component. The helper returns the relevant path, and thus the correct icon component is displayed. Name Status Note the use of the contextual component syntax {{component this....}} is used above to render a component from a dynamic path. Default options It is likely that most icon/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the a tick and failed will always use the alert. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponding returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the util as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return null. info

template:not-found.text: Not found This page doesn't exist. Head home?

template:templates/docs/default-options.title: Deafult options
template:templates/docs/default-options.text: Deafult options App wide options can be set in the emberSkeletonOptions object, which must be a child of in the ENV object in config/environment.js. The defaults are as follows: Any additional settings can be added to the emberSkeletonOptions object. These are made available in the options property of the emberSkeleton service. Theme color string defaults Allows you to define default settings for use by the ember-skeleton/theme-color-string helper. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. The above settings would allow the following three use cases. passed absent failed Theme icon defaults Allows you to define default settings for use by the ember-skeleton/theme-icon-string helper. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString.

template:templates/docs/helpers/array-jo.title: Array join
template:templates/docs/helpers/array-jo.text: Array join Pass an array as the forst argument and the join string as the second. You can optionally pass the named arg finalJoinString to use a different join string for the final item. Simple use List of Parks and Rec characters Custom finalJoinString My favourte characters are .

template:templates/docs/helpers/custom-i.title: Custom Inflector
template:templates/docs/helpers/custom-i.text: Custom Inflector Determines whether the singular or plural version of a word should be used. Accepts a number as the first argument, ad a hash of the singular and plural versions of the work or phrase. The plural version is optional- if not passed, the plural version of the phrase defaults to the singular version with 's' appended. has . has been voted for .

template:templates/docs/helpers/humanise.title: Humanise string
template:templates/docs/helpers/humanise.text: Humanise string Accepts a string as the first argument. Replaces underscores with spaces in the string, and applies one of three casing functions: sentenceCase (default) titleCase lowerCase upperCase Name Default Titlecase Lowercase Uppercase

template:templates/docs/helpers/in-array.title: In array
template:templates/docs/helpers/in-array.text: In array The first argument is an array, and then second is the string to find in it. Returns true if it is present, and false if it is not. Name Senior Junior Intern

template:templates/docs/helpers/odd-or-e.title: Odd or even
template:templates/docs/helpers/odd-or-e.text: Odd or even Accepts an integer as the first argument, and returns either odd or even. has an number of votes.

template:templates/docs/helpers/readable.title: Readable file size
template:templates/docs/helpers/readable.text: Readable file size Returns a human readable filesize, after receiving a number of bytes as the only argument. Rendering bug Note that versions of Ember lower than 3.18.0 you get unexpected results with long integers, when the integer is passed directly into the helper. The bug does not occur when the argument is in a property as above. (Should be 2.00GB)

template:templates/docs/helpers/replace-.title: Replace string
template:templates/docs/helpers/replace-.text: Replace string Receives a string to search for as the first argument, and then either a search tem and a replace term (simple search), or an array of search and replace hashes (advanced search). Note that the value of the default hash will be returned if the string is not found in any of the hashes. Note that the helper only looks for an exact matches- it does not replace text within string that is being searched. Simple Usage The example below replaces "Andy Dwyer" with "Andrew Dwyer". Name Status Advanced Usage Th example below replaces numerical statuses with string statuses. Name Status Array Note that you can pass an array as the find property in your advanced search hashes. The examples below replaces both "0" and "-1" with "false", and "1" with "true". Name Passed Using a find array with the advanced hash: Name Passed Fallback You can pass a fallback string to the helper. If no matches are found, the fallback dtring will be returned. The example below replaces "1" with "passed" and everything else with "did not pass". Name Passed Using fallback with the advanced hash: Name Passed If there are no matches and no fallback is passed, the original string is returned.

template:templates/docs/helpers/robotise.title: Robotise string
template:templates/docs/helpers/robotise.text: Robotise string Accepts a string as the first argument, and a separator as an optional second argument, which defaults to _ if absent. ` Name Default Custom separator

template:templates/docs/helpers/theme-co.title: Theme Color String
template:templates/docs/helpers/theme-co.text: Theme Color String Use case The styles documentation outlines how you can define a map of theme colours, which then generates classes for displaying a range of UI elements in any of the defined colours. See Theme colours and Theme colour CSS selectors in Styles". Often we want to associate strings in our data with certain colours- for example, a green badge for a data item with a status of complete and a red badge for an item with a status of failed, as below. complete absent failed With the badges above, the green and red backgrounds come form the badge-success and badge-danger classes respectively. But when using dynamic data, for example in the loop below, hard coding the class of the badge doesn't work- notice how each status below appears in a green badge. Name Status Likewise, simply passing in the status as he relevant part of the badge doesn't work, because there are no theme colours named passed, failed or absent. Name Status Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-color-string helper accepts a string as the first argument (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value is one of the defined theme colours. The helper returns the relevant theme colour, and thus, the badges below display correctly. Name Status Default options It is likely that most colour/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the success colour and failed will always use the danger colour. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js, for example as below. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the helper as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return the lowercased input string. info

template:templates/docs/helpers/theme-ic.title: Theme Icon
template:templates/docs/helpers/theme-ic.text: Theme Icon Use case Often we want to associate strings in our data with certain icons- for example, a tick for a data item with a status of complete and an alert for an item with a status of failed, as below. complete failed But when using dynamic data, for example in the loop below, hard coding the path to the icon component doesn't work- notice how each icon below is a tick. Name Status Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-icon helper accepts a string as the first arguemnt (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value the path to a component. The helper returns the relevant path, and thus the correct icon component is displayed. Name Status Note the use of the contextual component syntax {{component this....}} is used above to render a component from a dynamic path. Default options It is likely that most icon/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the a tick and failed will always use the alert. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponding returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the helper as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return null. info

template:templates/docs/index.title: What is Ember Skeleton
template:templates/docs/index.text: What is Ember Skeleton A frame for building Ember apps that: provides basic layouts for common app designs includes a custom styling API incoporates styles from existing frameworks like Bootstrap and Material Deisgn provides helpers and utils to make templating easier in a real world sense

template:templates/docs/layout-component.title: Content wrapper
template:templates/docs/layout-component.text: Content wrapper To be used inside either of the they panel or sidebar layouts. Creates what you could think of as the main content area of the page, and implements text styles for "main content" text. Accepts one argument- the main title to be displayed on the page. template:templates/docs/layout-component.title: Footer component
template:templates/docs/layout-component.text: Footer component To create your own footer component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/footer, or specify a custom path in the footerComponent property in your "app wide default options" . footerProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/footer-layout components, you can supply a hash as the footerProps property, and that hash will be available in your footer component.

template:templates/docs/layout-component.title: Header component
template:templates/docs/layout-component.text: Header component To create your own header component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/header, or specify a custom path in the headerComponent property in your app wide default options. headerProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/sidebar-layout components, you can supply a hash as the headerProps property, and that hash will be available in your header component.

template:templates/docs/layout-component.title: Loading component
template:templates/docs/layout-component.text: Loading component This is what will display in the main content area of your layout when in loading state. See page loading state" on how to show and hide the loading component. To create your own loading component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/loading-page, or specify a custom path in the loadingComponent property in your app wide default options". loadingProps When inserting either the ember-skeleton/panel-layout or ember-skeleton/loading-layout components, you can supply a hash as the loadingProps property, and that hash will be available in your loading component.

template:templates/docs/layout-component.title: Sidebar component
template:templates/docs/layout-component.text: Sidebar component To create your own sidebar component, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/sidebar, or specify a custom path in the sidebarContentComponent property in your app wide default options". sidebarProps When inserting the ember-skeleton/sidebar-layout component, you can supply a hash as the sidebarProps property, and that hash will be available in your sidebar component. collapseSideBarIconComponent By default, the sidebar is collapsible, and features an expand/collapse icon, which rotates 180 degress when the sidebar is collapsed or expanded. To create your own icon, you can either create a component in your app with the path ember-skeleton/svg/icon-collapse-sidebar, or specify a custom path in the collapseSideBarIconComponent property in your app wide default options".

template:templates/docs/main-page-layout.title: Panel layout
template:templates/docs/main-page-layout.text: Panel layout Created a layout with a horizontal panel spanning the full width of the screen. The content is centred within it. Invoked as below. Content here.

template:templates/docs/main-page-layout.title: Sidebar layout
template:templates/docs/main-page-layout.text: Sidebar layout Includes a sidebar to the left, and a main content section to the right. The content is aligned to the left of the main content section. Invoked as below. If content header is true, the class content-header is added to the wrapper div, and the styles add additional padding to the top of the right hand section (The main section) allowing an additional fixed bar to be placed at the top of the section. Content here.

template:templates/docs/page-loading-sta.title: Page loading state
template:templates/docs/page-loading-sta.text: Page loading state By toggling the hideContent property in the emberSkeleton service, you can toggle the main content area of your layouts between loading and loaded state. Your loading state will likely show some form of loading animation or gif, to indicate that a network request is in process. See layout components" on how to customise what displays in loading state. The example below shows how the loading state can be toggled at anytime, and from any Ember class that the emberSkeleton service can be injected into. Automatically toggling the loading state To automatically toggle the loading state of your layouts when Ember data is fetching data, define the loading action in your application route. Customising the loading component

template:templates/docs/styles/box-arrow.title: Box arrows
template:templates/docs/styles/box-arrow.text: Box arrows Adds an arrow to a box. The examples below show all the available combinations of arrow direction and position. .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-left .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-right .box-arrow.arrow-direction-left.arrow-position-top .box-arrow.arrow-direction-left.arrow-position-bottom .box-arrow.arrow-direction-down.arrow-position-right .box-arrow.arrow-direction-down.arrow-position-left .box-arrow.arrow-direction-right.arrow-position-bottom .box-arrow.arrow-direction-right.arrow-position-top By default, the arrow fill will be white, but if the element in question has any of the theme colours applied as a backgroud, the arrow fill will take in that colour. .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-left.bg-success .box-arrow.arrow-direction-up.arrow-position-right.bg-warning

template:templates/docs/styles/box-shado.title: Box shadow mixin
template:templates/docs/styles/box-shado.text: Box shadow mixin The box-shadow mixin accepts two arguments- the position and opacity. The default opacity is 0.16. There are 12 positions available: @include .box-shadow(top) @include .box-shadow(bottom) @include .box-shadow(left) @include .box-shadow(right) @include .box-shadow(topInset) @include .box-shadow(bottomInset) @include .box-shadow(leftInset) @include .box-shadow(rightInset) @include .box-shadow(bottomRight) @include .box-shadow(topRight) @include .box-shadow(bottomLeft) @include .box-shadow(topLeft) The mixin can be given a list of positions to add multiple box shadows to one element. @include box-shadow(topInset, rightInset, bottomInset, leftInset); Opacity can also be passed as the second argument. The default is 0.16. @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.1); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.3); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.5); @include box-shadow(bottomRight, 0.7);

template:templates/docs/styles/flexbox.title: Flexbox styles
template:templates/docs/styles/flexbox.text: Flexbox styles There are flexbox related classes defined in ember-skeleton/app/styles/layout/flex-layouts.scss.

template:templates/docs/styles/introduct.title: Introduction
template:templates/docs/styles/introduct.text: Introduction The styles are implemented using SASS, and thus the ember-cli-sass addon is required. Install by running ember install ember-cli-sass. There are two stylesheets which need to be imported in app/styles/app.scss. Overriding SASS variables All variables listed in app/styles/ember-skeleton/variables can be overridden. This must be done before the import of ember-skeleton-variables. Boostrap integration Several components of Boostrap 4.1 SASS code have been borrowed, some of which have been slightly modified. The original Bootstrap docs are listed below. Note that additional CSS classes have been added to some of these components in the Ember Skeleton SASS code. Bootstrap components Alerts Badge Buttons List group Bootstrap utilities Borders and border radius Colours

template:templates/docs/styles/miscellan.title: Miscellaneous classes
template:templates/docs/styles/miscellan.text: Miscellaneous classes .inline-block Applies display: inline-block to the element. .position-relative Applies position: relative to the element. .hidden Applies display: none to the element. .bg-transparent Applies background-color: transparent to the element. .hover-pointer The cursor will be a pointer on hover of the element. .monospace Applies the font family assigned to the $monospace-font-family variable to the element. The default value is "Lucida Console", Monaco, "Courier New", Courier, monospace. Spinner Any element with the classes .spinner.on will have a spinning animation. .spinner.on Other All elements have box-sizing: border-box. All elements with role="button" will have cursor: pointer in hover state.

template:templates/docs/styles/spacers.title: Spacers
template:templates/docs/styles/spacers.text: Spacers The SASS API allows you to define spacers, which are used to generate various classes. The defaults are: A version of each class listed below is generated for each defined spacer. padding-{{this.spacer}} padding-y-{{this.spacer}} padding-x-{{this.spacer}} padding-top-{{this.spacer}} padding-right-{{this.spacer}} padding-bottom-{{this.spacer}} padding-left-{{this.spacer}} margin-{{this.spacer}} margin-y-{{this.spacer}} margin-x-{{this.spacer}} margin-top-{{this.spacer}} margin-right-{{this.spacer}} margin-bottom-{{this.spacer}} margin-left-{{this.spacer}} height-{{this.spacer}} width-{{this.spacer}} max-height-{{this.spacer}} max-width-{{this.spacer}} Padding examples The padding is represented by the darker grey areas in the examples below. padding-xxl padding-md padding-x-xl padding-y-xl padding-left-xl Margin examples margin-xl margin-xl margin-xl margin-sm margin-sm margin-sm margin-x-lg margin-x-lg margin-x-lg margin-y-lg margin-y-lg margin-y-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg margin-bottom-lg margin-right-lg Height, width, max-width and max-height examples Extending spacers Add additional spacers to the $spacers map in your scss code, before you import ember-skeleton-variables, and ten use in your templates as shown below. Additional spacing classes margin-0 Sets margin to 0 padding-0 Sets padding to 0 width-100 Sets width to 100% last-child-margin-bottom-0 Sets bottom margin to 0, if the element is the past child. margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0 margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0 margin-bottom-xl last-child-margin-bottom-0

template:templates/docs/styles/text.title: Text
template:templates/docs/styles/text.text: Text Font size on the body elemnet Note that the font-size of the body element is hard coded to 62.5% so that within the body element, 1em = 10px. This makes it easy to use the superior em units to size fonts, while thinking of font sizes in pixels. Customising text Any of the variables defined in ember-skeleton/app/styles/ember-skeleton/variables/_text.scss can be overriden to customise text design. All overrides must happen before you import ember-skeleton-variables in your scss. Body text The .body-text class defines styles for the text that falls in the primary content areas of your layouts. This would typically exclude the header, footer and sidebar layouts, as you will likely want to style the text in these elements individually. The .body-text class will be applied to any content wrapped in the ember-skeleton/content-wrapper component (See layouts), but the class can be added to any element. See ember-skeleton/app/styles/ember-skeleton/generic/_text.scss to see all elements that are affected when they are descendants of .body-text. Text align The following classes apply the corresponding value to the text-align property. .text-align-left .text-align-center .text-align-right .text-align-justify Text smaller and text larger Default values (These can be overriden before importing ember-skeleton-variables in your scss.) $text-smaller-size: 0.9em !default; $text-larger-size: 1.2em !default; In addition, the .text-smaller and .text-larger classes Text column class This class is added for use with long form text blocks, so that such blocks can be styled for maximum readability. The following variables can be overriden before importing ember-skeleton-variables. Note that $text-column-justify-paragraph-min-width defines the minimum screen width at which paragraphs inside .text-column must have their text-align property overridden to justify. If null the paragraphs will not have their text-align property overridden. Links no-underline class If the class no-underline is added to any a element, it will not be underlined,in both normal or hover state. Faux link class The .faux-link class will apply all link styles to the element.

template:templates/docs/styles/theme-col.title: Theme color variants
template:templates/docs/styles/theme-col.text: Theme color variants Text colours text-primary text-secondary text-success text-info text-warning text-danger text-light text-dark text-gray-extra-light text-gray-light text-gray-medium text-gray-dark text-white Badges Taken from Bootstrap badge badge-primary badge-secondary badge-success badge-info badge-warning badge-danger badge-light badge-dark badge-gray-extra-light badge-gray-light badge-gray-medium badge-gray-dark badge-white Alerts Taken from Booststrap alerts A simple primary alertcheck it out! A simple secondary alertcheck it out! A simple success alertcheck it out! A simple danger alertcheck it out! A simple warning alertcheck it out! A simple info alertcheck it out! A simple light alertcheck it out! A simple dark alertcheck it out! Buttons Taken from Bootstrap buttons. The .btn class applies general button styles, and btn-{{this.theme-color}} or btn-outline-{{this.theme-color}} applies a theme colour. The class flashing will cause the button to flash between outline state to normal state. Primary Secondary Success Danger Warning Info Light Dark Link Primary Secondary Success Danger Warning Info Light Dark Adding the class flashing will cause the button to chnage between normal and outline state. Flashing button List groups Basic usage .list-group-item .list-group-item.list-group-item-action .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.active .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.disabled Flush Removes the side borders. .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item .list-group-flush .list-group-item List group with colour variants .list-group-item.list-group-item-action .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-primary .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-secondary .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-success .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-danger .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-warning .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-info .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-light .list-group-item.list-group-item-action.list-group-item-dark List group header The boostrap list group styles are extended by adding the class .list-group-item-header which applies the font weight defined the the variable $list-group-header-font-weight. The default is 600. Borders Taken from Bootstrap borders .border .border.border-primary .border.border-secondary .border.border-success .border.border-danger .border.border-warning .border.border-info .border.border-light .border.border-dark .border.border-white Border radius Taken from Bootstrap border radius .rounded .rounded-top .rounded-right .rounded-bottom .rounded-left .rounded-circle .rounded-0 Overlay colours Provides a set of classes that apply either a fill or background to an element in RGBa format, thus allowing transparency. The defaults provide both black and white at levels 10, 30 and 50. These numbers refer to percentage opacity. The classes are as follows: .overlay-bg-white-10 .overlay-bg-white-30 .overlay-bg-white-50 .overlay-bg-black-10 .overlay-bg-black-30 .overlay-bg-black-50 .overlay-fill-white-10 .overlay-fill-white-30 .overlay-fill-white-50 .overlay-fill-black-10 .overlay-fill-black-30 .overlay-fill-black-50 .overlay-bg-black-10 .overlay-bg-black-30 .overlay-bg-black-50 .overlay-bg-white-10 .overlay-bg-white-30 .overlay-bg-white-50 The $overlay-colors map can be extended in a similar way to $theme-colors. Additionally, you can customise the levels that are included. Note the the colours must be defined in RGB format. .overlay-bg-green-10 .overlay-bg-green-30 .overlay-bg-green-50 .overlay-bg-green-80 .overlay-bg-red-10 .overlay-bg-red-30 .overlay-bg-red-50 .overlay-bg-red-80 .overlay-bg-blue-10 .overlay-bg-blue-30 .overlay-bg-blue-50 .overlay-bg-blue-80 Fill and stroke colours The Bootstap theme colours have are extended to incldue fill and stroke, for application to SVGs. Overriding fill and stroke for elements inside an svg Note the following variables: $svg-foreground-graphic-fill $svg-foreground-graphic-stroke-color By adding the class foreground-graphic to any element inside an svg, the fill and stoke colours will be whatever the corresponding variables are set to (Default is #fff).

template:templates/docs/styles/theme-col.title: Theme colours
template:templates/docs/styles/theme-col.text: Theme colours This concept has been borrowed from Bootstrap. Many of the CSS classes available in the styles API are based on a map of theme colours, defined in the $theme-colors variable. The defaults are shown below. Theme color CSS selectors The Ember Skeleton SASS code will create multiple CSS style rules for each of the selectors listed below- one for each item in the $theme-colors map. See Theme color variants" for the full CSS API based on theme colours. .alert-* .badge-* .bg-* .text-* .list-group-item-* .fill-* .stroke-* .btn-* .btn-outline-* Button theme colours If you don't want the full map of $theme-colors applied to buttons, you can define a buttons specific map and pass it to the variable $button-theme-colors. The format is the same a the &theme-colors variable. This map of colours will then be used to generate the colour variants of the .btn-* and .btn-outline-* variants. Adding custom theme colors Custom colours can be added to this map, by defining your own $theme-colors map before importing ember-skeleton-variables. Note that the above code will add the colours to the default $theme-colors` map, rather than replace it. The corresponding classes will then be avilable in your CSS. The below example shows bootstrap badges implemented with custom theme colours defined above. badge-twitter badge-facebook badge-tripadvisor badge-reddit Bootstrap YIQ threshold Some bootstrap components apply bootstrap colours tot he backgrounds of elements that will have text in theme- for example .badge-* and .btn-*. In order for such text to remain readable, it may need to be dark in some cases, and light in others. Note that the Tripadvisor badge has dark text above, while the Reddit badge has white text. Both a light and dark text color are defined by the $yiq-text-dark and $yiq-text-light variables. The $yiq-contrasted-threshold variable is a measure of when a colour is light enough to require dark text on top of it. It can be anything from 0 to 255. The default is 160. The higher this value is, the lighter a background is allowed to be, while still maintaining light text on top of it. Att 255 text will always be white, and at 0, text will always be dark.

template:templates/docs/utility-componen.title: Material Card
template:templates/docs/utility-componen.text: Material Card Adds static classes to a component to give it rounded corners, large padding, a border and box shadow effect. Basic usage Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Depth The depth prop sets the depth of the box shadow based on the Google Material Design spec. The default is 1, max is 5. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Hover effect If the materialCardHoverEffect prop is true, a hover effect will be applied when the user hovers over the card. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Theme color integration Uses the defined theme colours" along with theme color string helper" to apply a coloured borde to the car, based on the borderColorProp. The simplest scenario is when borderColorProp is the name of one of the theme colours. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. The second scenario is where the borderColorProp is not one of the defined theme colours", but it is handled by the theme color string defaults in config/environment.js. | You can pass a hash of custom theme color string associations using the themeColorStringHash prop. Note that you can also pass fallback="..." to this hash to provide a fallback border color. See the theme color string helper docs" for more. | Usage by class extension You can make any component into a material card component by extending the material-card component class. import MaterialCard from 'ember-skeleton/components/ember-skeleton/material-card'; export default MaterialCard.extend({ ... });

template:templates/docs/utils/array-join.title: Array join
template:templates/docs/utils/array-join.text: Array join Pass an array as the first argument and the join string as the second. You can optionally pass the named arg finalJoinString to use a different join string for the final item. Example

template:templates/docs/utils/custom-inf.title: Custom Inflector
template:templates/docs/utils/custom-inf.text: Custom Inflector Determines whether the singular or plural version of a word should be used. Accepts a number as the first argument, ad a hash of the singular and plural versions of the work or phrase. The plural version is optional- if not passed, the plural version of the phrase defaults to the singular version with 's' appended. Import the util Usage

template:templates/docs/utils/custom-sor.title: Custom sort objects
template:templates/docs/utils/custom-sor.text: Custom sort objects Order an array of javascript objects according to a key, but rather than using ascending or descending order, specify an order by passing an array of values to be matched, in the relevant order. Objects in the array which are not matched are appended to the end of the returned array. RegExp can also be passed as an order item.

template:templates/docs/utils/odd-or-eve.title: Odd or even
template:templates/docs/utils/odd-or-eve.text: Odd or even Accepts an integer as the first argument, and returns either odd or even. Import the util Usage

template:templates/docs/utils/readable-f.title: Readable file size
template:templates/docs/utils/readable-f.text: Readable file size Returns a human readable filesize, after receiving a number of bytes as the only argument. Import the util Usage

template:templates/docs/utils/robotise-s.title: Robotise string
template:templates/docs/utils/robotise-s.text: Robotise string Accepts a string as the first argument, and a separator as an optional second argument, which defaults to _ if absent. ` Example Name Default Custom separator

template:templates/docs/utils/theme-colo.title: Theme Color String
template:templates/docs/utils/theme-colo.text: Theme Color String Use case In general, you should be using the helper" directly in your templates. The util should only be used when this is not possible. For a general explanation of the use case, see the helper docs". Import the util Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-color-string util accepts a string as the first argument (person.status in the example below), and an object as the second argument, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value is one of the defined theme colours. The helper returns the relevant theme colour, and thus, the badges below display correctly. Name Status Default options It is likely that most colour/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the success colour and failed will always use the danger colour. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js, for example as below. The util will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponsing returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the util as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return the lowercased input string. info

template:templates/docs/utils/theme-icon.title: Theme Icon
template:templates/docs/utils/theme-icon.text: Theme Icon Use case In general, you should be using the helper" directly in your templates. The util should only be used when this is not possible. For a general explanation of the use case, see the helper docs". Import the util Basic usage The ember-skeleton/theme-icon helper accepts a string as the first arguemnt (person.status in the example below), and a hash of key value pairs, where each key is a potential value of person.status and each value the path to a component. The helper returns the relevant path, and thus the correct icon component is displayed. Name Status Note the use of the contextual component syntax {{component this....}} is used above to render a component from a dynamic path. Default options It is likely that most icon/string associations will remain consistent throughout your app- for example that passed will always use the a tick and failed will always use the alert. To avoid having to explicitly pass these associations to the helper every time it is used, a set of app wide defaults can be defined in config/environment.js. The helper will check if the value of the first argument is present in any of the matchStrings arrays, and will return the corresponding returnString. Note that you can set fallback: true on one of the objects. In this case, the returnString of that object will be returned if no matches are found. Note that this can be overriden by passing fallback to the util as outlined below. Name Status Note that where a key value pair passed directly to the helper conflicts with a default association, the default association will be overriden. Name Status You can also pass a fallback string to the helper then invoking it. This will be returned by the helper if no other matches are found. missing If the string passed to the helper does not find any matches, and no fallback is given, the helper will return null. info
